content:
advertisement

Some Penn State colleges reported that state budget cuts could result in unfilled faculty and staff positions PERIOD

and Michele Jarchin

After a pair of midyear state budget cuts different colleges within Penn State may have to compensate by cutting back on salaries and staff student activities and research programs PERIOD

Robert Steele dean of the College of Agricultural Sciences said if these cuts become permanent many positions within his college will not be filled depending on the severity of the cuts PERIOD

 Steele said PERIOD 

He added that the colleges research and extension programming areas have felt the effects most strongly PERIOD

Richard Durst dean of the College of Arts and Architecture said in order to make up for the budget cuts staff had to withdraw money from the colleges operations budget PERIOD

 Durst said PERIOD Cheryl Achterberg dean of the Schreyer Honors College said the college will have to cut from its technology budget PERIOD

 Achterberg said PERIOD

Starting next year the college will combine two staff positions into one and decrease the number of Scholar Assistants who run scholarfocused student programming in Simmons and Atherton halls PERIOD

 Achterberg said PERIOD

Douglas Anderson dean of the College of Communications said there are three effects that come into play due to lack of funding PERIOD

 Anderson said PERIOD 

In addition Anderson said his college has had to hold off on ordering some lab equipment in basic computer labs as well as put off some improvements to facilities and labs PERIOD

 he said PERIOD

Responding to concerns about the recent midyear cuts at the University Faculty Senate meeting Tuesday Penn State President Graham Spanier said he is concerned about future impacts they will have on the university PERIOD

 Spanier said PERIOD

But he said the university has a lot of other sources of income that provide Penn State with a fair amount of flexibility PERIOD

Penn State is governed by a philosophy to do nothing to sacrifice  within the university he added PERIOD

 Spanier said PERIOD 

No matter how bad the economic situation is Penn State tries to maintain a modest salary increase each year Spanier said PERIOD There has only been one year when Penn State did not raise salaries he noted PERIOD

This academic year the state government has taken back a total of . million in funding from Penn States initial  appropriation of . million PERIOD These cuts follow another series of reductions that affected the university last year PERIOD Penn States appropriation  . million  is now . million below where it was at the beginning of the  academic year PERIOD
